div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,584] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.
The weather yesterday was similar, but the night was damp. This morning opens dull, damp, and cloudy with a light easterly breeze and a steady barometer. Some rain drops fell at 8 a.m.

div.head: THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
div.p: The programme of the founders of the proposed National University should have the eff rot of modifying the criticisms passed in advance up in that institution. The fears to which some of our Egyptophobes—for there are - Egyptophobes as well as Anglophobes to be, found in Cairo and Alexandria—gave utterance, presaging a "Nationalist” University with Mistapha Pasha Kamel or some vigorous and intolerant member of the ulema class as its Rector, are shown to be groundless, and the pronouncement of the committee that the doors of the new University shall be thrown open to all, whatever their origin and their religion, who desire to learn, and that its constitution shall be entirely independent of political ii fluences, is reassuring. Nor is the programme of the University courses too restricted, while none can accuse it of a lack of idealism. In fact, even some of the sympathizers with the movement may feel a certain doubt whether those who have drawn up the programme may not have sought to soar, like Icaru, too near the sun on their first (light. But we should like to remind our readers that Kassim Bey Amin's letter does not contain a definite programme : the University will not open tomorrow, nor will students crowd to Cairo this winter to attend its lectures. Some years of patient work are required before the University can be finally established. Funds must be raised and a site must be chosen.

The constitution of the governing body must be determined, and professors discovered, who are capable of teaching Oriental students. We will reform later to some of these points. Meantime, we must realise that we have to do with a very admirable and public-spirited proposal made by men whole spirit is progressive, whose enthusiasm is unbounded, and whose aims are free from the taint of self-interest. To those who assert that the motives of the promoters of the scheme are interested, reply that if the University is to be a successful and well-organised foundation, there will be no room for private profit. The founders will, indeed, obtain some of the immaterial rewards of public spirit—the criticism of the ignorant and the praise of the enlightened; but, even should their first essay be u fruitful, their names will be famous among their compatriots and also among all men whom love of knowledge and admiration of a genuinely patriotic spirit render indifferent to the distinctions of creed and race. And in the days to come each men will abound.

Our critics—we foresee their appearance— may deny our premises. Bat, after all, if they assert that the scheme will founder through disunion, they must remember that the new- born zeal for education may yet carry Egyptians safely past the Scylla of jealousy and the Charybdis of intrigue, and if they that the scheme is doomed to fall into dishonest hands, we can only reply that if the University Committee diverts the subscriptions it will receive into improper channels, we—and not only we but all Egypt—are absolutely mistaken in our judgment of the honesty and single-mindedness of its members.

We have remarked that the programme which Kassab Bey Amin has suggested and outlined may not meet with the approval of all the world. But it is capable of mod fication, and if the public to which it is addressed has criticism to offer, none can doubt that its criticisms will have weight. But we should like to point ont that till now the curse of Egyptian education has been the view taken by Copts and Moslems alike, that education exists to enable young men to obtain positions under Government or to crowd certain professions that once were lucrative but are now overcrowded by the multitude of competitors. We admit that education in the present state of society mast be for most a means to snob an e d. But "man shall not live by bread alone." The nations have succeeded best which have aimed as far as possible at a wide training—the training of the mind and of the body, and the training of the will. China is the classic instance of failure, due not so much to the predominance of a purely literary education, as to the prevalence of the idea that the head and end-all of education was the supply of mandarins. France and England at the present day, Rome and Greece in the past, have realized that each over-specialisation is almost as dangerous as neglect to the body politic, that education when possible mast be something more than a means to wealth.

applies too well to an education that is concentrated on the production of money-makers. A modern State does not require citizens turned out like coin from a mint—uniform, stamped with the same pattern and the same mailing. It needs numbers and variety, specialists and handicraftsmen, active workers and watchful critics; even the idle rich—pace our Socialists—have their vaine once their intellects or their characters or both have been disciplined or trained. A millionaire may devote b's wealth to the advauo6ino.it of knowledge ; a poor man may become a leader in the councils of his people.

Thus far neither the Egyptian Government nor the Egyptian people have had the time or the means to create a University. A system of secondary and technical education has achieved much, but it has not given—nor in the nature of things could it give—the opportunity to zealous students of acquiring a wider knowledge. The young Egyptian of means has too often fallen a victim to his own indolence. His secondary studies completed, he bas seized on the absence of any system of higher education as an excuse for apathy, has learnt nothing new, and forgotten all he has already learnt. The unemployed (or ill-employee) rich abound among us. If the new scheme finds intellectual employment for even a section of them, it will have done much. It will have done more if it succeeds in imbuing the average man with the idea that his education is not necessarily finished because he can make L.B. 5 a month ; it will have fulfilled the aspirations of its founders if it can produce scholars who are in touch with practical life and practical men, whose natural eagerness for self-improvement is mellowed and refined by genuine love of knowledge.

We wish the committee rapid and complete success. If they can work together, if they can overcome jealousy and mistrust, if they can overccome that inertia which is a deadlier foe than active opposition, they must succeed. And their success may have far reaching elects. What happier fate could be in store for Egypt if at the very gate way of the East there arose a University destined to harmonise East with West, to be in concord with the proud and manly spirit of Islam, the ideas that Judas, Greece, and Rome have handed down to the Western world I.

div.head: Egyptian Gamblers
div.p: It is estimated that the Egyptian “jennesse dorée” have lost L.E, 200,000 in gambling this season at Vichy.

div.head: The Midday Gun
div.p: The noon gun at Cairo Citadel was not fired on Monday owing to the snapping of the electric wire between it and the Observatory.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's bulletin reports the admission to hospital at Alexandria of a Greek waiter belonging to a café in the Qnmrnk quarter is a case of bubonic plague.

div.head: Theft of L.E 800
div.p: "AlMnkattam” publishes a telegram from its Tala correspondent stating that the sum of L E. S00 has been stolen from the Tala Markaz cashier at Batanonn.

div.head: Luxor Chaplalnoy
div.p: The new Anglican chaplain at Lnxor is the Rev. Mr Raens The Rev. Grose, the former chaplain, is not, coming ont this year, having taken an appointment in Switzerland.

div.head: Wakfa Board
div.p: A meeting of the Wakfis Board will be held in Cairn this afternoon under the presidency of Ahmed Sbafik Bey, chief of the Khedive's Bureau

div.head: The French Consulate.
div.p: M. de Reffye has postponed the first sitting of the French Consular Court, Cairo, for the trial of civil oases and charges of misdemeanour until the middle of November.

div.head: Fatal Cart Accident
div.p: At Hagar Nawatieh, Ramleh, yesterday, a native youth was run over by a vegetable cart, and sustained injuries to which be succumbed this morning.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The P. & O.'S.S. Osiris arrived at Port Said at nine o'clock tins morning with mails from Europe. The distribution at- the G.-P. O., Alexandria, will commence at 9 o'clock this evening.

div.head: Land for State Railways
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways Administration has deposited the snm of L.E. 14,500 with the Native Tribunal of First Instance for the expropriation of lands at Miniet el Sirg.

div.head: Khedival Agricultural Society
div.p: The British barque Heathfield (Captain Fraser) iB discharging a cargo of about 9,800 tons of nitrate of soda for the Khédivial Agricultural Society from Iqniqne, Chili, which she left just before the recent terrible earth- quake.

div.head: Agricultural Bank Bonds.
div.p: The National Bank of Egypt announces that scrip of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt three- and-a half per cent, guaranteed bonds may now be exchanged for definitive bonds to bearer. Scrip must be listed on forms to be obtained from the National Back of Egypt, 1 and 5, King William-street, E. C., and left three clear days for examination.

div.head: Naval Funeral.
div.p: First-class Domestic R.Cole,of H.M.S.Venos, whose death we recorded yesterday, was buried at the British Protestant Cemetery, Rosetta Gate, this morning. The mortal remains of the deceased were accompanied to the cemetery by a firing party from the cruiser and the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers.

div.head: Post Office Savings Bank.
div.p: During the month of September 1,129 per- sons deposited the sum of L.E. 33,500 in the Post Office savings bank, which, added to the sum remaining is the bank on the first of that month, gives a total of L.E. 322,822. During the same month L.E. 28.733 were withdrawn, so that the balance doe to depositors on the lit September was LE. 294,089.

div.head: New Large Jewish School.
div.p: New Large Jewish School.

div.head: Arrivals.
div.p: The steamers from Europe are arriving here full ; it is said that never before have there bean so many arrivals. A good many of the passengers Lave taken advantage of their sojourn in France, Italy, England, or Germany to improve their knowledge of the languages of those countries. They will resume the lessons begun in the Berlitz Schools of Europe either in Cairo (Sharia Kamel) or in Alexandria (12 rue Rosette),, and they will not notice the least change in the method, for it is exactly the same everywhere. [Advt.]

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt-. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: LONDON' OPINION-
div.p: The way in which the London money market has been drained to meet the Egyptian demand lead in the "Statist" to remark :- "It is too early yet to estimate with any confidence the probable Egyptian demand. Until recently that demand was expected to be small, because speculation is much less active than it was at this time last year. Now opinion has changed, and it is feared that the demand will be large. Quite possibly, in a little time further we may see another change of opinion, or the Bank of France may decide upon supplying Egypt freely. It would not be wise, however, to depend upon that. Ever since 1870 the policy of the Bank of France has been to keep as large an amount of gold as it possibly can. Just now there are many reasons why the Bank of France should think it desirable to maintain that policy. The state of Russia, the general disturbance of the political equilibrium in Europe, the unrest, among the Mohamedans, and the uneasiness at home, are all reasons why the Bank of France should think it undesirable to part with very large amounts. It is true that there has been a very considerable decrease in the gold held by the Bank of France. Bat then it is not possible from the returns to ascertain to what extent that decrease is for internal and to what extent for external requirements. Therefore for the present it would be beat to assume that the Egyptian demand upon this country will be nearly as large as in recent years."

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RETURN.
div.p: Our Port Said Correspondent telegraphs that Lord Cromer arrived there by the P and O. steamer Osiris this morning,- and left by special train for Cairo, where he is due to arrive at 4^ pm. Hafiz Eff. Ibrahim, the wall-known native poet, intends to submit to Lord Cromer an Arabic poem which he has composed, relating to the varions events which have occurred in Egypt daring his lordship's absence. The poet points out that the Egyptians have not changed and never will, but the charge brought against them after the Denishwai incident was a bitter pâli for them. Addressing his stanzas to Lord Cromer, the poet adds: "Had you been here to see the Denishwai affair people would not have been tortured."

div.head: FRONTIER COMMISSION.
div.p: The Nnhr el Bahr has left Suez for Akaba, where she will probably embark those members of the Frontier Commission who are returning by sea to Suez.

div.head: NEW BARRACKS FOR ABBASSIEH.
div.p: A board of officers is to meet at Headquarters, Cairo, on Thursday next in order to | consider the question of the site and the construction of barracks for the Army of Occupation at Abbassieh. The board will be com- posed of Col. G. J. Cuthbert, A.A.G , president, CM. J. Magill, M.D., C.B., R.A.M.C., Col. A. W. Roper, R.E., and Lieut.-Col. E. A. Herbert, M.V.O., loniskilling Dragoons.

div.head: SALE OF SIRDAR'S ISLAND.
div.p: Atran Island, commonly known as Sirdar's Island, which was bought from Lord Kitchener some four years ago by Mr. G.D. Faber, C.B., junior Member of Parliament for York, has been sold to the Government for L.E. 9,000. Atrun Island, situated on the Nile at Assouan, is the most beautiful of Egypt's isles, and is very rich in cultivation. It covers an area of over ten feddans.

div.head: LOTTERY CIRCULARS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The introduction of a penny post between England and Egypt has led to the practice of dispatching Hungarian lottery circulars to England viâ Alexandria. The postage from Hungary would be two pence half penny, and as the circulars are sent off in quantities of 50,000 or more at a time the Buda-Pesth lottery mongers can effect a very substantial saving by forwarding them in bulk to be posted here. It is hoped that the Postmaster General in England will ascertain whether Lord Cromer cannot pat a stop to this misuse of the Egyptian Post Office.

div.head: MOHAMBDAN RIGHTS IN INDIA.
div.p: The Mahomedan community in India, as represented by their delegates at Simla, since presenting their memorial to the Viceroy. have been discussing the best means for safeguarding their interests. It has been decided, in the first {lace, to organize provincial associations which should send representatives to a central body. The further organization of the scheme, particularly with reference to that body and its fonotionsi, will be discussed at Dacca, where the annual Mahomedan educational conference assembles in December. The main object is to keep the Government authoritatively in famed as to local Mahomedan feelings and aspirations. Methods of agitation such as those employed by the National Congress will be can fully avoided.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: Messrs. Colliege Brothers cable as follows : - Weekly Bureau. Crop accounts generally unfavourable ; too much rain and frost.

div.head: DISORDERLY CONDUCT IN CAIRO-
div.p: Yesterday morning, the hearing of a sum- mons brought by Mr. Mathurg, proprietor of the St. James's Hotel, against Mrs. Adams took place at H.B M.'s Consular Court, Cairo. The defendant was represented by Maître Geoffrey Miward. It appears that a few days ago, Mrs. Adams's little daughter entered the St. James's Hotel, wherb she fell into conversation with a couple of officers, who gave her ices, sweets, etc and appears to have become rather excited, and eventually began to threw ices from the window of the hotel on to the heads of-those who were having supper below. This conduct naturally provoked a scene, .and the child wag requested to leave; the-hotel, the proprietor of which giving orders that she should not be admitted in future. On the following evening Mrs. Adams appeared, and sitting down at a table which, was already occupied, began to talk loudly , to the diners, who. seem to have objected, and Mrs. Adams was ordered to leave the hotel. At about three o'clock in the morning she re-appeared, driving up in company .with her husband, and daughter,. and .entered : the .hotel, whore she created considerable disturbance, violently abusing Mr. Marbarg, - who was eventually obliged to send for a policeman. Mrs. Adams was then removed, loudly pro- testing, and drove away. She afterwards re- turned, however, and for some time drove up and down in front of the hotel, uttering loud and free comments on the conduct of the proprietor. Her defense was that aha had sent her daughter on the previous day to find a doctor, who she believed wa9 having supper there, to ask him to come at once to. visit, her husband, who was seriously ill. The Court criticized the defense on the grounds that Mr. Adams's illness was not so serious as to-pre- vent him from going on a moonlight drive with his wife and daughter. Mrs. Adams was fined £2.

div.head: SIGNIFICANT MOVE OF TROOPS.
div.p: The "Moayad" reports that a detachment of the British Army of Occupation will march from Cairo to Shibin el-Kom on the 20th inst. The troops will be encamped there for several days. The Menoufieh mondirieb, having ; received orders to prepare a site for the camp, has selected a plot of land about 8 feddans in extent situated outside the town. The inhabitants of Menoofieb, on hearing of the contemplated visit of the troops, have been much perturbed, and are in hopes that it is for no other reason than the exercising of the troops. We understand that the rumour that the troops are to be permanently stationed, at Shibin el Kom is absolutely without foundation.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of the commencement of the month of Ramadan H.H. the Khedive will hold on Friday a reception at Ras-el-Tia, to take place in the following order : —
8 p.m — The Ulema ; the Princes of the Khédivial Family ; the heads of State administrations.
8.30 p.m.-The magistrates of the Mixed Tribunals ; the magistrates of the Native Tribunals ; the officers of the Army and Navy of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards ; the civil officials.

9 p.m.-Civil and military non officials, with the ranks of Lewa or Onla Sinf S and upwards ; officers of the Army and Navy retired or en disponibilité, with the rank, of Miralai or Kaimakam ; non-official Beys- with the rank of Montemaiz or SaDieh ; the mem- bers of the Municipal Commission.
9.30 p.m.-Native merchants ; the civil and military household of H.H. the Khedive and the Khédivial Khassa.
The reception is exclusively reserved for persons resident at Alexandria The military will attend in undress uniform and civilians in frockcoats (redingotes).

Civil officials admitted to this reception must have at least the rack of sub director (or an equivalent rank) and the grade of Sanieh or Kaimakam (military), .as well as magistrates nominated by decree.
Her Highness the Khedivah will receive the same day, between 8 and 10 p.m., the Princesses of the Khédivial Family and native ladies only.

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE MOHAMED.
div.p: The "Mokattam" says that Lord Cromer has telegraphed to these concerned with the appointment of a tutor to the children of the late Prince Mohamad Ibrahim-asking them to postpone any decision until his return.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITY.
div.p: The provisional committee of the proposed ! Egyptian University has published a second list of fourteen subscribers, whose contributions amount to L.E. 2,350. The subscriptions now total L.E. 6,935. M. Lietto Acher, a well known member ft the Jewish community in Cairo, has offered £200.

To the Editor of the "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,-I hope I shall not be trespassing unduly on your valuable space by replying to the arguments addaced to support the view that "Al- Minbar" is of a "dangerous character," and that by reason thereof the authorities were justified in prohibiting its entry into the Sudau. I should in the first instance point out that the term "suppressed," in that relation, was erroneously employed, seeing that no copy of our publication had ever been sent into the Sudan. Permission was asked soon after our journal made its appearance to authorise its transmission in the Sudan ; and that permission has recently been refused upon no stated grounds, though it is clear that those responsible thought it inexpedient to let the paper into circulation. With this decision I do not quarrel, because I have no doubt that it was sincerely arrived at, but what 1 do regret is that the authorities should not have taken care to be better informed. Had they been able to read our articles in the original instead of being obliged to treat to others less scrupulous and honourable than themselves, it would, I doubt cot, have been patent to them that "Al- Minbar," far from being inimical to their interests, has from the first initiated a policy favourable to them. Speaking at the dinner given by the Press to Major Owen Bey on the occasion of our return from the opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway, and subsequently on more than one occasion in print, I expressed the opinion that the Sudan should be regarded as part and parole of Greater Egypt and that the interests of the two are indissolubly bound np together. So, too, as regards the question of Egypt's contribution towards the expenditure in the Sudan. "A1 Minbar" has invariably upheld the present arrangement on the grounds just stated, namely, that the two countries should be regarded as forming an integral. Can those views be regarded as in any sense "dangerous 1" But to come to matters more immediately at issue. "A1 Minbar" is uoousod oi having disseminated a statement by an anonymous German attributing to tho English the invention of cholera and plague without at once contradicting it. Tho answer is simply this : The report was that of an interview with a well-known German Orientalist who did not wish his name disclosed. Now I would ask. Is it necessary to criticize in every such easel I should say not. To take the most recent instance : "The Pall Mall Gazette" published a lengthy report of an interview between its Paris correspondent and the editor of "El Lewa" containing many statements which, from the English point of view, were "exceedingly dangerous" and the report ot the inter- view was reproduced in "The Egyptian. Gazette" on the 12th iost. In neither instance was any editorial comment appended thereto. I ooald o'te hundreds of other instances of an identical description. It must, therefore, I think, be taken as clear that an editor is not bound to deny every statement published in his paper on the authority of a third party, which he knows or has reasonable grounds for believing to the nntrne, and hence that aconsation falls to the ground. But "A1 Minbar" is farther charged with unduly eulogizing the Ottoman Empire. All that I can say, in reply, is that whilst acknowledging H.I.M. the Sultan as the Khalif of Islam, and expressing our loyalty to the Khalifate, we have never forgotten to point ont the reactionary tendencies of the present Turkish Government, which like other governments will have its time and pass away. And how could it be possible for any mind endowed with a semblance of logic to a9k in one breath for perfect liberty and equality on behalf of the Egyptians without at the same time condemning the autocratic Government in Turkey 1 The thing is manifestly absurd "A1 Minbar's" policy has throughout been "Egypt for the Egyptians." To show that we have maintained that view I bag leave to quote from a leading article in "A1 Minbar" of the 24th July last in which the following passage occurs "The Egyptians desire to be inde- pendent without nemg under any autocrat either in Yildiz, Abdin, or Kasr El Doubara." Of course we at the same time defend the integrity of the Turkish Empire and desire to see it regenerated and strong again amongst the nations of the world. Again we say that no ope who has a grain of political sense or experience can doubt that for Egypt to be come again a Turkish vilayet, as- it was before the time of Mohamed Aly, would be the gravest of all misfortunes for our country The allegation that our journal charged British consuls and missionaries with instigating the Armenians to rebel is without foundation The Armenians were never referred to by ns at all in this connection.

div.head: PRIMITIVE PICTURE WRITING.
div.p: A very important essay relating to the primitive art and culture of the ancient Egyptians is that of M. George Fonoart, Sur la Decoration des Vases de la période dite de Naggadeh," read by him before the French Academy.

The subject, as stated by M. Fonoart, does not include all the pictorial ornamental styles upon this primitive pottery, but is restricted to an explanation of tbe meaning of a tableau frequently found, in more or less modified form, and well known to Egyptologists.

This is a sort of panorama depicting a boat, with elevated prow and stern, containing a kind of naoa, looked at our sorily appearing to be merely two piles of timber united near their summits by a connecting bridge. From one of the masses of freight or elsewhere on the vessel projects a flagstaff, or guidon pole, bearing emblems ; whilst one or more palms extend from the stem.
In the field of the picture are people with their arms uplifted, or carrying boomerangs, gazelles and large birds, and a few small pyramidal objects, which have been thought to indicate hillocks.

M. Fouoart's theory, which is a most interesting one, is that these scenes indioate a time when Egyptian writing had Dot passed out of the pictorial stage. These scenes upon the pottery are in fact true hieroglyphs, and are really a primitive panoramic display of what subsequently became the verbal proaoynem of the funeral stelte, which in itself, when for private personages, was but a copy of worship offered daily to the deities in their temples ; and with extra splendour, in these edifices or outside them, at the special fêtes of the gods.

The following is M. Fouoart's interpretation of the scenes depicted, and it will immediately appear how appositely his theory accounts for them. The boat with its long rows of oars is the "barque divin" which every Egyptian god had in his temple for the purpose of conveying him in a procession on land, or if used only as a .symbol of the deity's voyage across the celestial ocean or river, he embarked upon it and prooeoded in prooeaipn on the Nile.

The boat emblem therefore conveyed the idea that the tête of a god was intended. Then Ice double oouaeoted pieces of cargo are representation of the temple pylons, indicating, therefore, a religious festival proceeding from the deity's earthly mansion.

The pole, or flagstaff, with its particular emblem floating from it, explains which god's fête was intended ; and it is most remarkable that M. Fouoart has bean able to select from these boat banners at least ten guidons, whose figures he shows are the sacred symbols of as many divinities. These, as might bo ospoatxsd, correspond in most oases with the anoint name Totem gods we know from other ralios of the very earliest Egyptian art. The one or more palms at the prow or stern of the vessel, indicate the number of days' duration of the festival, whilst the people with hands and arms uplifted acclaim the passage of the sacred baroque.

Finally, the deer, t birds, and triangular objects all refer to the great festival sacrifices, and stand, pictorially, for the well-known rubric inscribed, as it was reoited, upon the funeral stel and temple rituals of later date, which it will be remembered commence by promising a feast oi "thousands of gazelles and of birds and loaves, or cakes," these latter being represented in the vase tall Bans by the little pyramidal objects.

The stelei texts ..also include (as does the "Paooarte" or "Table of offerings formulae," a derivative from them) staffs and vestments, and these M. Fouoart sometimes finds shown upon the vase drawings standing in bales, especially on pottery found at Naggadeh. So these pictures are the prototypes of the tomb paintings and reliefs; and. which is even more important, they are the pictorial symbolic representation before the later hieroglyphs developed into the determinatives and letters of the literary inscriptions upon the funeral steele, and finally of the same texts when engrossed upon the sepulchral papyri.
JOSEPH OFFORD.

There appear to be four species of gazelles depicted on the Naggadeh objects, and these therefore correspond to the four gazelles said, in a tomb text at Hieraconopolis, to be the canonical number to be utilised for sacrifices.

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS CO.
div.p: The Upper Egypt Hotels Company is making rapid progress towards the completion of its new hotel at Laxor, which is virtually finished and, will happened on New Year's Day. Mr. Pagnon, managing director of the company, arrives at Luxor on Saturday next to put the finishing touches to this palatial establishment. All the furnitre, and fittings have arrived at Alexandria or are on their way from England. The hotel will accommodate nearly two hundred guests
The company has also been greatly improving its second caravanserai at Laxor, the Laxor Hotel, of old resort, whioh has been entirely renovated.
At Assouan the Cataraot Hotel is being got ready for receiving guests in the coarse of next month.
The company has made some important repairs and renovations in the Savoy Hotel on E'ephantine Island. It will be opened in December.
The Grand Hotel at Assouan has remained open all the summer and will keep open until the reopening of the Savoy and Cataract Hotele.
Luxor has assumed quite a new aspect since the new hotel, the Winter Palace, has been built, for by its erection a promenade on the river bank has been created.
We regret to learn of the illness of Princess Saliha Hanem, widow of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim.
Colonel (temporary Major General) George M. Bullock, C.B., Commanding the Army of Occupation in Egypt, has been promoted to the full rank of Major General.

A distinguished member of the Khédivial staff has been home on leave, and has just returned to Egypt, says the "Court Journal," This is Major J. K. Watson, late of the King's Royal Rifles, who is an aide-de cusp of the Khedive, and the first British officer to be permanently employed in that capacity. Major Watson retired last year after twenty years' service, daring which he had seen much fighting in Bormah, in the Sudan, in the Dangola and the East expeditions, andin South Africa. In the campaign which culminated in the overthrow of the Mahdihe was oidadeoarop to Lord Kitchener, and in Sooth Africa he aoted as his military secretary. Captain Watson received the D.S 0. for the Dongola expedition, the C.M.G. in 1900, and the M.V.O. last year. He is forty-one and is married to. A daughter of Mr. H. C. Nisbet, of the Old House, Wimbledon.
Judge Bond, vice-president of the -Native Court of Appeal, is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 20th inst., on his return tram England viâ Port Said.
Judge Batcheller, of the Mixed Court of Appeal, has returned from leave and is now staying at San Stefano.
Adly Pasha Yaghen, Director-General of Wakfs, is expected to return to Cairo from Europe at the end of this month.
Herr von Wnnderliqh, German Consul at Alexandria, is expected to arrive next Monday by the S.S. Hohenzallern.
Mr. Frank Haseldon, Mr. and Mrs. Crafton, and Mr. Carver arrived at Alexandria from Port Said this morning by the Khédivial liner Assouan.
Mohamed Bey Ali Bt-8hadili, Governor of Damietta, has been granted two months and 12 days' leave, to date from the 26th inst.
Mr. George Stevenson, general-manager of the Telephone Company, will arrive from Europe to-morrow.
Lieut. A. H. Wodebouse, Ist Sattalion Royal Dublin Pasiliers, has been granted leave of abaeuoe on the recommendation of a medical board for three months.
Mr. R. L Delaqais has been elected honorary secretary to the Deutsche Sportsverein.

Mr. Henry S. Wellcome, who established the Wellcome Research Laboratories at the Gordon Memorial College, Khartoum, three years ago, has sent a donation of fifty guineas towards the endowment fund of the London School of Tropical Medicine.
A marriage has been arranged between Mr. Max Stross, son of Mr. Adolph Stross of Alex- andria, and Miss Piara Odeiro. Laraggi, of Genoa.

div.head: COPTS AND MOHAMEDANS.
div.p: A young Coptic student at The Law School, Cairo, has aroused great indignation, among his comrades by his denial of the existence of Mohamed as the Prophet of Islam. His fellow students asked him to give them the statement in writing, which he did, and Jthe7 then referred the matter to the acting director of the school. He, however, declared that such matters were not within o his province and advised the students to take the matter before the Parquet. This advice was followed and the case will be heard shortly.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor arrived at Liverpool last Sunday.
The Ellerman S. S. Arbabian sailed last Sunday from Liverpool with a general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.
The Ellerman S.S. City of- Venice- sailed from Malta yesterday noon, and is done here on Saturday morning next with passengers and ageneral cargo.
The S.S. Carib Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 16th inst., and is due at Alexandria on Saturday morning.
The S.S. Royal Prince left Malta on the 15th inst. with passengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Friday.
The Canard S.S. Pavia sailed direct for Liverpool yesterday afternoon with a fall cargo, including 3,878 bales of cotton.

div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Après un début en réaction, la cote s’est feu à peu relevée à la suite de la haussa accentuée de quelques titres. L’Union Fonoière, qui était négligée depuis longtemps aux environs de 6 livres, viei.t d’être l’objet d’une forte demande tant locale que du Caire qui a fait monter le prix à 6 5/16. De nombreuses transactions ont é é effectuées à ce cours et l’on s’attend à une coitinuatiou de la hausse, motivée par l’excellente situation de oette société. Beaucoup d’affaires également en National Bank, Sait à Soda, Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land, Estates et Comptoir. La Sait and Soda monte de 22/3 à 23/6, la Cassa di Sconto de 233 à 234, les Tramways Privilégiées de 185 à 187, la Béhéra de 38 A 40 vendeurs, les Markets de 27/3 à 27/6 ex coupon, et la Nile Land de 16 3/8 à 16 1/2. Par oontre, la Delta L'ght perd I /32 à 11 29/32, la Daïra 1/16 à 16 13, 16, les lots Turce 1 fr. 50 à 146, la Banque d’Athènes 50 centi-mes à 144 1/2, la Delta Lan I 1/32 à 3 3/4, le Comptoir 1/32 à 6 31/32, et la BJlding Lands 1/32 à 5 1/32. Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres a été élevé hier de 1/4 à 4 7/8 poor cent par suite de nouveaux grands retraits d’or pour l’Egypte. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 86 5,8 et l’Uirûée à 1C4 1/2. La National Bank a haussé de 5/8 à 27 1/2. L’Agricole est demeurée iucbargée à S 7/8. de même que la D»ira à, 17. La Delta Light a encore gagi é 1,8 à 12. A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a c’ô'oré en avance de 3 francs à 781. La Banque d’A'hènes a regagné 1 frano à 145. L'omprnut rosse 19ü6 a passé de 83.80 à 84.50. De même qu’hier, nous avons eu, ce matin, on marché actif et animé des meilleures dispositions. Les transactions ont été nombreuses et, ma'gré des réalisations importantes, la demande a constamment primé l’offre. Aussi bien la fermeté a dominé snr tonte la ligne et il y a encore h enregistrer des plus-vaines sur la plupart d68 prix da olcffare de la veille. Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a débuté à 27 3/8 ponr fléchir à 27 1/8 et c'ôturer à 27 3/16-1/4. L’Agricole a progressé à 9 13/16 7/8 et la Cassa di Soonto à 231 232. Le Comptoir Financier s’est inscrit à 7 1/8 l’aotion ancienne et 6 15/16 la nouvelle. La Banqne d’Abyssinie est revenue à 5 9/16. L’action Crédit Fonoier a été traitée à 780 ; l’obligation à lots ancienne a molli à 336-337. La Béhéra a avancé à 38 1/4. La Nile Land 63t restée à 16 1/2 ; la part de fondateur est retombée à 85. Les Improvement/iontatteint £6. En excellente tendance, Tadtion Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a gagné 1/8 à 4 1/2; la part de fondateur, très recherchée, a haussé à 94. L’action Allotment s’est raffermie à 3 J/2; la part de fondateur a clôtaré à 132. L’Union Foncière a été négociée à 6 6 1/16. Le Wardan Estate a faibli à 6 7/8. La Delta L'ght a avancé à 11 15/16 12. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont été bien tonnes à 264 265. Les Automobiles ont été ootées 6 5/8 et la part de fondateur 12 1/4. La Frigorifique a rétrogradé à 4 3/4. L’Anglo-American Nile a progressé à 5 9/16 5/8. Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les NnDgovich ont é-é ponssés à 18 3/8-7/16. Les Egyptian ont atteint en clôture le prix de £ 7. Les Upper Egypt se sont maintenus à 5 3/16. Les National ont gagLé 1/16 à 4 1/16 ; la part de fondateur a passé à 77. Parmi le3 petites valeurs, c’est la New Egyptian qui a eu encore les honneurs do la matinée. Largement éohangéa d’un bout, à l’antre de la séance, elle a olôturé entre £4 sh. 9 et 35, gagnant un shelling et demi. Les Delta Land ont atteint les abords de 3 15/16 ponr réaotionner à 3 13/16 ot finii plGS fermes à 3 7/8. Les Estates se sont consolidés à £ 2 ; la part de fondateur a avancé à 13 15/16. Les Markets ent été traités à 27 sh. 6, ex-ooupon. Les Constructions ont été cotées 1 1/2-9/16, les Abdy 1 1/4-5/16, les Qlymenoponlo 1 3/8 7/16, les Khédivial Mail 36 sh. et les Sucreries 25 26 francs. Les Hooker ont été demandés à 1 1/8 sur la rameur que le domaine de Jonr-bal aurait été finalement vendu. Les Oasis ont progressé à. 1 3/16-1/4 et les Sait and Soda à 22 sh. Nous détachons d’ane lettre de Paris, en date du 9 Octobre, le passage suivant : Il semble que notre marché abase un peu de la santé da Sultan pour déprimer cours de la Rente tntqne, ainsi que ceux des valeurs ottomanes en général. Que le Padischah soit malade, cela ne fait pas de doute ; que pour ce fait, on impose à ces valeurs une certaine réserve, cela se comprend ; maié de là à faire de la baisse il y a an abîme.Eq effeh en admettant même l’hypothèse que l’on semble redouter le plus, qu’y aurait-il de changé, même en Tarquie? U homme, oui ; ane institution, non; un système financier enoore moins. Il est impossible qu’en finance, oa toat an moins pour ce qui regarde les porteurs de la Dette Ottomane, il y ait quelque ohose de changé. Le décret de Moharrem a mis ces porteurs à l’abri de tous les aléas : caprices de Sultan, ordres de sacoession au trône ou révolut-ons de palais. La Commission internationale de la Dette fait simplement respecter ses droits, exerce une surveillance constante sur la perception des taxes et des impôts qa’elle administre et dont elle est chargée de faire la répartition. Par conséquent, quoi qu’il arrive, aucune crainte sérieuse pour les porteurs, que le Sultan soit jeune ou vieux, fi's on neveu de son suzerain bien portant ou ma'ade. Bref, pour les détenteurs, la santé du Padischah f eut être considérée comme un acoeasoire ; leur Sultan à enx, c’est l’administration internationale de la Dette.” Le lancement da ‘ Virginia”, bateau-touriste de l'Express Nile Steamers Co. aara lien demain, è 4 h. de l'après-midi, à l’arsenal du Bahr el Aïua, près du Pont des anglais, à Ghizeh. Ce batsau, onstruit d’après le type de ceux qui naviguent sur le MLsidsipi, a une longueur de 150 pieds et une largeur de 21. Toute la partie en avant du pont supérieur sera occupée par un grand salon entièrement vitré. Le "Virginia” fera exclusivement le service entre Looxor et Assouan. Ls lancement d’un autre bateau de la Compagnie aura lieu très prochainement. On annonce deLmxor que le Winter Palaco Hôte1, de 1’Upper Egypt Hotels Co., sera complètement terminé vers la fiu du mois pro chain, de sorte que oe grand établissement pourra travailler toute la saison.
